title: Tuesday, 25th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:02am

Been a particularly nutty 24 hours, at this end

PM11:03am

Mainly thanks to Kadhim and this

11:02 am
PM11:03am

https://ftalphavil...ial-coin-offering/

PM11:03am

And all the other ICOmedy stuff

PM11:03am

Lefevre -- haven't seen Izy's tweet

11:03 am
PM11:03am

But it will be related to ...

PM11:03am

https://www.bitstocks.com/

PM11:04am

Some chap on her train this morning, wearing a Bitstocks tee-shirt

11:04 am
PM11:05am

But I should mention -- I think Kadhim has identified a defining feature of this particular investment madness

PM11:05am

It's, the use of the random, comma.

PM11:05am

Thank you. Together, we can, build, a future.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Go read some of the coin offering gibberish.

PM11:06am

You'll see, that the random, commas are, everywhere.

PM11:06am

Been led down all sorts of alleyways

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Things like this

PM11:06am

PM11:06am

That's the chap behind Monkey Capital

11:06 am
PM11:07am

Which collapsed yesterday Omg smile

PM11:07am

After our little pop on Friday

PM11:07am

Down about 46% I think

11:07 am
PM11:08am

What happens here is that -- in the interests of journalism -- we join the various Slack channels set up by these people

PM11:08am

To see what they are saying.

PM11:08am

Most of it's not suitable for a family audience -- like you lot on the right

11:08 am
PM11:08am

But it leads us to stuff like this: http://www.marxrand.com/archives/242

PM11:09am

When Alex Wilhelm, the popular Tech Crunch journalist, found himself inside Boston Logan airport confronted at 3.30am by a dry bar, he blasted out loud on Twitter: "What time do they start selling alcohol in Boston?" Soon after, Daniel M. Harrison and Wilhelm struck up an agreement: Wilhelm would write a story about his predicament for Marx Rand and Harrison would pay him the princely sum of $1000 for the privilege. What follows is the one and only unedited example today of first person narrative journalism on the subject of personal anguish written by a leading chronicler of the disruptive technological revolution. Fearless and daring, Wilhelm is adored for both his distinctive turn-of-phrase as well as his occasional scathing critique of the anti-technology brigade and Wilhelm's voice is one that has come to define how this contemporary consumer-economic revolution is written about. "Don't Be An Alcoholic At The Boston Airport" is the raw, unedited version of what is a funny, witty, jarring and despairing and self-deprecating, and above all, genuinely creative portrait of a brief snapshot in time within the life and mind of one of the most influential technology writers of our day and age.

PM11:09am

Anyway, enough of that madness

11:09 am
undefined
PM11:10am

Re-melt-up-ish this morning

BE11:10am

The invention of the group chat has indeed been a bane (or, if you prefer, a bone) of journalism. I have to keep my eye on approximately 90 Telegram chatrooms that are nothing apart from guys putting up gifs of Leo DiCaprio and banging on about the same three stocks.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

But, yes, melt up. That's something to mention.

BE11:11am

FTSE ahead 0.8% at pixel.

BE11:11am

Dividends, mostly.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Informa, Anglo, etc.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,105, up 13 (+1.19%), High: 1,106, Low: 1,073, Volume: 6.50m
PM11:11am

(A. M. -- it's not parody. It's just wasted middle class youth burning their parents' money.)

11:11 am
Informa PLC (INF:LSE): Last: 675.50, up 0.5 (+0.07%), High: 676.00, Low: 666.50, Volume: 9.13m
BE11:12am

.......... which we'll get to eventually.

BE11:12am

First, though, there's Choo.

11:12 am
Jimmy Choo PLC (CHOO:LSE): Last: 195.00, up 2.5 (+1.30%), High: 195.50, Low: 191.25, Volume: 79.39k
PM11:12am

Choo??

PM11:12am

Missed this

11:13 am
BE11:13am

The only company listed I know of that's called Jimmy. And now it's departing.

BE11:13am

Michael Kors agrees to pay 230p.

BE11:13am

(Is our auto pricing not working? I don't think it is.)

11:13 am
PM11:14am

Pricing is stale

PM11:14am

Live is 228p

BE11:14am

Cash offer agreed by JAB Luxury, which owns 67.6% of Choo.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

So, that's that. Done.

BE11:14am

Pierre Denis, Sandra Choi get to keep their jobs.

BE11:15am

Should be complete Q4 17

11:15 am
BE11:15am

So. £896mn market value, 17.5x 2016 EBITDA

BE11:15am

There are a couple of interesting sidebars to this, and they're largely on the Kors side.

PM11:16am

(This thing floated at 140p, three years ago)

11:15 am
BE11:16am

The first is for reasons mostly historical.

BE11:16am

Because there were a lot of punters in Kors, and they seem to have been disappointed.

BE11:16am

You might remember that back in November, the idea was that Kors was near the late stages of auctioning itself.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

With Inditex, LVMH and PVH among those mentioned as having an interest.

PM11:17am

I do remember this

BE11:17am

The idea at the time (as in November, please note: this isn’t live) was that PVH put forward the most attractive proposal. Mid $60’s per share and Kors management got to stay on.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

However, we checked it out with everyone and never got comfortable enough to write anything.

BE11:17am

That decision seems to have been justified by the lack of news since

PM11:17am

Indeed

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Which coincided with an idea that Kors is rather too entrenched in its namesake brand, where margins aren't fantastic

BE11:18am

As of now, it's paying a rather exciting price for another .... middling, shall we say? .... brand.

BE11:19am

With no payback before 2020.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And that's on some rather ambitious growth forecasts.

BE11:19am

They want to grow Choo to be a $1bn business

BE11:19am

It did £364m sales last year.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

So .... doubling sales via the Kors distribution network, which demands a lot of department stores?

PM11:20am

Well ambition's a good thing. But it does feel rather like a handy exit for JAB Luxury

BE11:21am

Yep, Jab only wants coffee these days.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Remember when we wrote Jab was a motivated seller of Choo about a year ago and lots of people shouted at us?

BE11:22am

Ah well.

PM11:22am

I do

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Quick line from Piper, which is the only broker I've seen that's not conflicted and also up at 4am New York time.

BE11:22am

The CHOO brand ran at a premium GM to KORS in the last two years combined, generating a ~63% GM vs. KORS in the 59/60% range. A higher SGA rate (50% range) vs. KORS' upper-30% range created a lower EBIT rate vs. KORS' (LDD vs. high-teens). We want to better understand how KORS intends to run CHOO more profitably to derive a path towards accretion in FY2020.

BE11:22am

• Timing Comes At A Bit Of A Surprise Given KORS New 2020 Plan: While mgmt. has talked about M&A over the last year (not too dissimilar from Coach's playbook back at the time of their June 2014 Analyst Day), we would have expected M&A to be slightly further out given the focus to turn around the namesake brand. While we, too, were surprised by the timing of when Coach bought Stuart Weitzman (announced in early 2015), that deal was considerably smaller vs. the KORS/CHOO deal at a purchase price of $574M vs. $1.2B. Further, KORS/CHOO multiple is higher (at 17.6x) than the COH/ KATE (9.2x), COH/Stuart Weitzman (12x) and the Samsonite/TUMI (14x) acquisition on an EV/EBITDA basis.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

• VFC Talks About Improved M&A Environment Just One Day Ago: Separately, note this acquisition comes one day after VFC management indicated they are seeing more activity in the M&A space over the last three months as multiples start to look more compelling. Further, this transaction is a U.S. company purchasing a U.K. domiciled company where the USD to Pound Sterling relationship is ~flat Y/Y at £1 =$1.30, albeit not as favorable as the FX rates were earlier in the year at $1.20.

BE11:23am

(VFC is VF Corp, a collection of kind-of-okay brands like Timberland, Vans and North Face. It’s a $24bn company, I learned this morning.)

BE11:23am

(One of those $24bn companies I'd never previously heard of.)

11:24 am
BE11:25am

https://www.ft.com...-93ff-99f383b09ff9

BE11:25am

New-build houses in England will no longer be sold on a leasehold basis as the government seeks to end “long-term financial abuse” by developers.

Sajid Javid, the communities secretary, will propose a ban on Tuesday that will prevent homebuyers from paying more than a token ground rent to freeholders.

A recent government report found that 4m private homes in England, or one in five, are leasehold.

Leaseholds used to be associated almost entirely with flats, reflecting the fact that a block of apartments needs some form of communal upkeep.

But there are now 1.2m houses on leases, after large builders including Taylor Wimpey, Persimmon and Galliford Try started to sell their properties on that basis, especially in the North West.

BE11:25am

So, this would've been significant a few years ago.

11:25 am
PM11:26am

Why not now?

BE11:26am

By now, though, the house builders have all recognised that this particular form of profiteering was outrageous and likely unsustainable.

BE11:26am

They had to keep their eye on the bigger prize, which is the Help to Buy subsidy being maintained at all costs to the nation.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

So, Taylor Wimpey has already written in a bunch of settlements to its numbers.

BE11:27am

For the others, the impact going forward is likely minimal.

BE11:28am

Even for Berkeley which, since it's in the London rabbit-hutch market, relies on leaseholds for arguably justifiable reasons.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

(@ GBKrona: tell me about it. My service charge has doubled in five years.)

BE11:29am

Let me get some JP Morgan Cas to say "meh".

BE11:29am

Overall, for the housebuilders under our coverage,
we expect the impact on profits from no longer being able to bundle up ground rents and sell them on to
investors, to be small. Berkeley sales are focused on leasehold apartments, therefore we assume the impact is
highest here, and ground rent sales were disclosed as being c.£27m in the last year, equating to 3% of profits,
assuming there are no costs associated. For the other housebuilders we cover, we expect the impact to be very
low single digit at most, and most likely capable of being offset by upgrades from elsewhere. Taylor Wimpey
has already taken the step of stopping selling houses under a leasehold basis at the start of this year, from which
there was no disclosed impact on profits.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Now, proper leasehold reform would be great. But it doesn't seem to be a priority.

BE11:30am

(@ Pseudonym: have you ever met a solicitor?)

BE11:30am

Hence, the market's shrug.

The Assessments assert that BGML owes the Government a total of approximately US$154 billion, and PML approximately US$36 billion. The Assessments claim a total of approximately US$40 billion of alleged unpaid taxes and approximately US$150 billion of penalties and interest owed. Acacia disputes these assessments. The Company is considering all of its options and rights and will provide a further update in due course.

PM11:32am

fitness and the benefits of consistent product investment give us confidence that we will meet our financial and operational targets for 2017, including further growth in revenue, earnings, cash flow and dividend

(That'll slow a bit in the second half; apparently events are first-half weighted. I don't know why.)

BE11:39am

Overall, we see limited need to change forecasts.
Currency is a small head wind offsetting better growth at the margin. The interest cost in H1 suggests a small downgrade for this for the full year. Overall EPS of 47.1p may reduce by 0.5p – less than 1%. In 2018, despite the dollar adjustment, we are again not looking for much of an adjustment.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

That's Peel Hunt.

BE11:40am

A strong performance for H1 with results comfortably ahead of both our and
consensus estimates. A +3.7% underlying growth in the period is a very good
performance to our +2.5% expectation. Stand out is exhibitions at 11% (NSe +8%)
but Academic also worthy of note at +1.2% (NSe +0.5%). A significant number of
moving parts in estimates with the strong H1 offset by a potentially weaker $ in H2
and small dilution from the disposal of Euroforum, the net result a likely low single
digit upgrade to our EPS for the year (though we are a little ahead of consensus).
We retain our ADD and 825p target.

BE11:41am

That's Numis.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

You get the idea.

undefined
BE11:41am

Elsewhere, untimely departure at Mediclinic.

11:42 am

Danie Meintjes has done his time, having been CEO since 2010.

BE11:42am

Retiring by end July 2018.

PM11:42am

Rather sudden

11:42 am

PM11:43am

(I read 2018 as 2016, sorry)

Well, he's a year before his contractual retirement age of 63 so it's not entirely unexpected.

11:43 am

However, it's also at a tricky time for Mediclinic

Mostly because it didn't have enough doctors to keep it functioning

Profit warning followed profit warning, and now the CEO's off ski before that integration process is even complete.

BE11:45am

You'll also remember that Mediclinic's rather generous exec pay packages have raised some eyebrows.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

I don't have time to grab while typing live, but do find the latest annual report and spin to the pay and extras section.

PM11:47am

http://annualrepor...c_Plc_complete.pdf

BE11:47am

For a company that knackered itself via a botched acquisition, Mr Meintjes is coming out of it rather better than the shareholders whose money he spent.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Then, of course, there's the Spire question.

BE11:49am

And the rumour that "Mediclinic will be buying the 70% of Spire it doesn't own soon, or imminently, or not imminently, or maybe a bit after imminently, but definitely please write this because my spread betting account is looking very sickly."

BE11:50am

What do we read into the departure of the CEO here, with reference to Spire? I'd not see it as a bull signal, but whatever.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Citi hedges its bets.

BE11:50am

Implications for Spire: We believe it is a Buy- and Sell-side consensus expectation that Mediclinic will, in the future, attempt to take Spire wholly owned; we have argued this since initiation. We do not have a view on when such an offer might materialise, but we do not think the timing will be impacted by this management change (whether deferred or expedited).

BE11:51am

And on the wider question ........

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Of the stocks in our CEEMEA healthcare coverage,
we feel Mediclinic is amongst the least dependent on single members of the management team. Rather, the direction of the company is collectively driven by input from the CEO, CFO, the Executive Management Team, the Board and the controlling shareholder, Remgro. We believe that this is an attractive quality for institutional investors in the name, and it gives us comfort that a change in CEO should be a relatively smooth process

undefined
BE11:52am

Virgin Money requested .........

11:51 am
Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 289.45, down 17.05 (-5.56%), High: 302.00, Low: 276.80, Volume: 6.19m
BE11:52am

Numbers fine, mix of how they got there is a concern.

BE11:53am

It's also a reminder of what Virgin does, which is balance transfers

11:53 am
BE11:53am

.... on spectacularly long 0% APR offers.

BE11:54am

.... as in, 30 months or so before it ratchets up, and its accounting for the overall values of that debt has been questioned by some as a bit optimistic.

PM11:54am

Bank of England warning on this specifically just last night, of course

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Yup, it all falls into a theme. So, as of today, we get CET1 missing consensus by 30bp

BE11:55am

NIM looks light

PM11:55am

(Alex Brazier -- http://www.bankofe...97fa5e51-111054549 )

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Goodbody summarises the main worries better than I can

BE11:56am

VM reports net income (pre-dividends, AT1) of £90.5m, 11% behind
Virgin Money has this morning reported interim results for the six months to 30th June 2017. Virgin Money’s results are behind expectations with net income (predividends, AT1) of £90.5m, 11% behind our forecasts of £101.3m (though c.2% behind consensus). The key difference being a 7% variance on net interest income of £288.5m, trailing our forecast of £309m and higher operating costs mainly due to higher digital investment. Capital is also weaker than anticipated.

BE11:56am

H117 NIM was 1.59%, down 1bps on FY16 levels, with deposit repricing and increased TFS drawdowns, offset by further asset yield compression. Virgin Money has noted that mortgage spreads are anticipated to face pressure and that the FY17 NIM is likely to be at the lower end of the 1.57%-1.60% guided range. Elsewhere, Virgin Money reported a H117 cost of risk of 13bps (versus our 16bps expectation), with Virgin Money noting that the IFRS 9 loan loss adjustment is likely to be lower than the previous internal estimate of £50m.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Net loans came in at £34.7bn, modestly ahead of our expectations for £34.4bn. This reflects strong gross new mortgage lending of £4.3bn in the period, broadly in line with our £4.4bn forecast. At end-June, net mortgage balances stood at £31.8bn (£31.6bn forecasted). Virgin Money reported continued growth in credit card balances +4% q/q to £2.8bn, consistent with our £2.8bn forecast. Elsewhere, customer deposit balances increased by £0.6bn q/q to £29.6bn at end-H117. Virgin Money accessed an additional £2.4bn of TFS funding in Q217 to £4.9bn at end-H117. The LTD ratio rose to 117% (+250bps).

BE11:57am

Fully loaded CET1 ratio was 13.8% at end-H117, 140bps below end-FY16 levels with the benefits of retained earnings growth more than offset by balance sheet growth (mainly on new lending), uptick in operational risk (c.£100m) and intangible growth. RWAs were £8.8bn at end-H117, 5% ahead of our expectations, with CET1 capital up just 4% since December.

BE11:58am

The weaker capital position and lower NIM guidance are likely to be negatively received by the market. We are likely to reduce our FY17 NIM forecast of 1.66% on the back of updated NIM guidance. Overall, we are negative on Virgin Money due to potential risks to income and credit card losses in the cards book in time. We believe regulatory action (primary) to limit interest free periods and/or macro deterioration are likely to be ultimate catalysts for these issues to manifest.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Several brokers, Merrill for one, saying the fall's overdone

BE11:59am

Only have the Merrill desk note though, so instead here's Investec.

PM12:00pm

Trader Gordon a buyer i presume

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Another robust performance in H1 2017 which (we think) should drive material further consensus upgrades. In particular, we highlight (1) net mortgage lending in Q2 of £1.2bn, £2.1bn in H1 2017, so consensus of £1.5bn in H2 2017 and £3.0-3.3bn in 2018/19 look highly unlikely, (2) growth in Virgin’s super-prime cards portfolio to £2.8bn, which suggests its £3.0bn year-end target remains comfortable, and (3) an H1 2017 impairment charge of just £22.2m (13bps) which must surely trigger fresh corrections too?

BE12:00pm
